# Introduction to Microbiology ðŸ¦ 

Welcome to **Microbiology** - the study of life too small to see!

## What you'll learn:
- **Bacteria** - Prokaryotic cells
- **Viruses** - Not quite alive
- **Fungi** - Decomposers and more
- **Protists** - Diverse eukaryotes
- **Microbes & Humans** - Disease and benefits

> ðŸ’¡ **Fun Fact:** Your body contains more bacterial cells than human cells - about 38 trillion bacteria!

## Types of Microorganisms

| Type | Cell Type | Examples |
|------|-----------|----------|
| Bacteria | Prokaryotic | E. coli, Streptococcus |
| Archaea | Prokaryotic | Extremophiles |
| Protists | Eukaryotic | Amoeba, Paramecium |
| Fungi | Eukaryotic | Yeast, mold |
| Viruses | Acellular | Flu, COVID-19 |

## Why Study Microbiology?

- ðŸ¥ Understanding disease
- ðŸ’Š Antibiotic development
- ðŸ§¬ Biotechnology
- ðŸž Food production
- ðŸŒ Environmental cycles

slides.content:
# Viruses ðŸ§¬

## Are Viruses Alive?

**Arguments for:**
- Have genetic material
- Evolve
- Reproduce (sort of)

**Arguments against:**
- No cells
- No metabolism
- Can't reproduce independently

> Most scientists say NO - they're on the edge of life.

## Virus Structure

## Virus Types

|-----------------|--------|
| DNA, double-stranded | Herpes |
| DNA, single-stranded | Parvovirus |
| RNA, single-stranded | Flu, COVID-19 |
| RNA, double-stranded | Rotavirus |
| Retrovirus (RNAâ†’DNA) | HIV |

## Shapes

| Shape | Example |
|-------|--------|
| Helical | Tobacco mosaic virus |
| Icosahedral | Adenovirus |
| Complex | Bacteriophage |
| Enveloped | Influenza |

## Host Specificity

- Viruses are very specific
- Bacteriophages infect bacteria
- Plant viruses infect plants
- Animal viruses infect specific animal cells

> ðŸŽ¯ **Key Point:** Viruses can ONLY reproduce inside living host cells!

slides.title: Viral Replication
slides.content:
# Viral Replication Cycles ðŸ”„

## Lytic Cycle

Virus destroys host cell.

```
1. Attachment (virus binds receptor)
        â†“
2. Entry (injects genetic material)
        â†“
3. Replication (copies DNA/RNA)
        â†“
4. Assembly (new viruses built)
        â†“
5. Lysis (cell bursts, releases viruses)
```

## Lysogenic Cycle

Virus DNA integrates into host genome.

```
1. Attachment & Entry
        â†“
2. Integration (become prophage)
        â†“
3. Replication (with host DNA)
        â†“
4. May remain dormant for years
        â†“
5. Can switch to lytic cycle
```

## Comparison

| Feature | Lytic | Lysogenic |
|---------|-------|----------|
| Host cell | Destroyed | Survives |
| Speed | Fast | Slow/dormant |
| Symptoms | Immediate | Delayed |
| Example | Cold virus | HIV, herpes |

## HIV: A Special Case

```
1. RNA virus enters T cell
2. Reverse transcriptase: RNA â†’ DNA
3. DNA integrates (provirus)
4. Can lie dormant for years
5. Eventually destroys immune system (AIDS)
```

## Viral Diseases

| Virus | Disease |
|-------|--------|
| Influenza | Flu |
| SARS-CoV-2 | COVID-19 |
| HIV | AIDS |
| HPV | Warts, cancer |
| Rabies | Rabies |

> ðŸ’¡ **Key Point:** Antibiotics DON'T work on viruses - they only target bacteria!

## Characteristics

- Eukaryotic
- Cell walls (chitin, not cellulose)
- Heterotrophs (absorb nutrients)
- Most are decomposers

## Types of Fungi

|-------|--------------|----------|
| Zygomycota | Zygospores | Bread mold |
| Ascomycota | Ascospores | Yeast, morels |
| Basidiomycota | Basidiospores | Mushrooms |
| Deuteromycota | Asexual only | Penicillium |

## Roles of Fungi

### Beneficial
- **Decomposition:** Recycle nutrients
- **Symbiosis:** Mycorrhizae with plants
- **Food:** Mushrooms, yeast (bread, beer)
- **Medicine:** Antibiotics (penicillin)

### Harmful
- **Plant diseases:** Rust, smut
- **Human infections:** Athlete's foot, ringworm
- **Food spoilage:** Mold on bread

## Yeast

Single-celled fungi.

```
Sugar â†’ Alcohol + COâ‚‚ (fermentation)
      â†“          â†“

```

## Lichens

Symbiosis: Fungus + Algae/Cyanobacteria

- Fungus provides structure, water
- Algae provides food (photosynthesis)

> ðŸŽ¯ **Key Point:** Fungi are nature's recyclers!

slides.title: Microbes and Disease
slides.content:
# Microbes and Disease ðŸ¥

## Pathogens

Microorganisms that cause disease.

| Pathogen | Disease Examples |
|----------|------------------|
| Bacteria | TB, cholera, tetanus |
| Virus | Flu, COVID, measles |
| Fungi | Athlete's foot, thrush |
| Protist | Malaria, dysentery |

## Koch's Postulates

Proving a microbe causes disease:

1. Found in all sick individuals
2. Isolated and grown in pure culture
3. Causes disease when introduced to healthy host
4. Re-isolated from experimental host

## Chain of Infection

```
Reservoir â†’ Exit â†’ Transmission â†’ Entry â†’ Susceptible host
```

## Transmission Methods

| Route | Examples |
|-------|----------|
| Airborne | Flu, TB |
| Contact | Cold, skin infections |
| Vector | Malaria (mosquito) |
| Food/water | Cholera, Salmonella |
| Body fluids | HIV, hepatitis B |

## Preventing Infection

| Method | How it works |
|--------|-------------|
| Vaccination | Train immune system |
| Hand washing | Remove pathogens |
| Antibiotics | Kill bacteria |
| Antivirals | Slow virus replication |
| Sterilization | Kill all microbes |

## Antibiotic Resistance

```
Antibiotic use â†’ Most bacteria die
    â†’ Resistant survivors reproduce
        â†’ Resistant population
```

**Superbugs:** MRSA, XDR-TB

> âš ï¸ **Warning:** Overuse of antibiotics accelerates resistance!

slides.title: Beneficial Microbes
slides.content:
# Beneficial Microbes ðŸŒŸ

Not all microbes are harmful - most are essential!

## Microbiome

The community of microbes living in/on your body.

### Gut Microbiome
- Aids digestion
- Makes vitamins (K, B12)
- Trains immune system
- Affects mood and health

## Industrial Uses

| Industry | Microbe | Product |
|----------|---------|--------|
| Food | Yeast | Bread, beer, wine |
| Food | Lactobacillus | Yogurt, cheese |
| Medicine | Penicillium | Penicillin |
| Biotech | E. coli | Insulin production |
| Cleaning | Various | Bioremediation |

## Environmental Roles

### Nitrogen Cycle
- Nitrogen fixation (Rhizobium)
- Nitrification
- Denitrification

### Decomposition
- Recycle nutrients
- Break down dead matter

### Bioremediation
- Clean up oil spills
- Break down pollutants

## Biotechnology Applications

| Application | How microbes help |
|-------------|-------------------|
| Insulin | Bacteria produce human insulin |
| Vaccines | Grown in cell cultures |
| Biofuels | Fermentation to ethanol |
| GMO crops | Agrobacterium transfers genes |
| Gene therapy | Viral vectors deliver genes |

> ðŸ’¡ **Perspective:** Only ~1% of bacteria are pathogens - most are harmless or helpful!
